description._content: Buns, Germs and Seals April is the month that the few remaining harbor seals in New York gather in the water surrounding Swinburne Island to mate. The tiny island sits between Coney Island and Staten Island. Prior to its present usage by the seals, it was also, to a degree, a mating space for humans. The former quarantine facility was closed down in 1911 after Arthur Denyse was brought up on charges that he and his fellow employees were conducting orgies in the office. This hand silk-screened tablecloth, designed for the Brooklyn Artists Ball, is based on 19th Century wallpaper patterns in fashion at this time of glory, featuring the island’s present inhabitants. The Brooklyn Ball 2011 celebrates the art, creativity, and influence of Brooklyn artists and the Museum’s role as a cultural gateway. This year’s Ball is being designed in partnership with Brooklyn artists to create an evening filled with art, ideas, and surprises. Felicia Wong photo, Brooklyn Museum
